moves.1. f4: As expected.  I've played Ian several times over the years.  I still don't really know what to do against Bird's Opening...
moves.1... d5 2. e3 Nf6 3. Nf3 Bg4 4. Be2 Nbd7: Not sure that this helps White's cause as Black can attack the chain head on and White has few attacking options.
moves.8... b6 9. b4 a5: Not entirely sure that this was right either but it worked out OK.
moves.10. bxa5 Rxa5 11. Nb3 Ra7 12. cxb6 Qxb6: I liked my open acres on the Q-side and was determined to restrain the remote isolated passed pawn.
moves.16. Rf2 c5 17. dxc5 Nxc5: At this stage, with every move Black's position seems to improve.
moves.23... Nxc5 24. Rb1: An interesting offer of the exchange...
moves.27. Qd3 Qf6 28. Qb5 Qd8 29. Kh2 h6 30. B: ?! Dubious because White now traps this R on its one square... However, it doesn't seem fatally trapped
moves.31. Bd4 Rc8 32. Rb2 Qc7 33. Qa6: With this move, White offered a draw.  As I had a significant time and material advantage, I rejected the offer.
moves.33... Rb8 34. Ra2 Rxd4 35. exd4 Qxf4+ 36: Already a pawn and the exchange up, Black has swapped the R for a B and 2 pawns, so is still material up: 3 pawns.
moves.37. Qd6 Rb2+ 38. Rxb2 Qxb2+ 39. Kh1 Qf2: Now Black looks like winning White's last two pawns while keeping his well protected chain of pawns.
moves.40. Qd8+ Kh7 41. g4 Qg3 42. h4 Qxh4+: ??? a moment of carelessness loses the game.  I tried to retract my move momentarily but of course my opponent insisted on touch and move.  I had no excuses.  I had plenty of time left (about half an hour) whereas White had less than 10 minutes.
The K couldn't move.  Moves by d or e pawns were suicidal.  ...h6 was similarly suicidal.  ...f6 lost immediately to 48. Qg8++.
moves.48. Qg8+ Kf6 49. gxf5 Kxf5 50. Qh7+ Kf4: At this point, with my opponent on about 6 minutes left, I pointed out that he needed to write up his last 20 moves in his own time and an arbiter agreed.  He did that and then didn't have to record any more...
